message: I'm offering you a great deal on a premium product for $10000. It's a one-time opportunity that you won't want to pass up. Trust me, it's worth it!
I'm not convinced that the product is worth the price, and I'm not willing to take the risk without knowing its quality.

I understand your concerns, but I'm willing to sweeten the deal. I'll give you a 100% guarantee that you can return the product if it's not up to your expectations. And, I'll throw in a special bonus: if you buy this product, I'll give you a personalized consultation to help you get the most out of it. It's a $5000 value, absolutely free. So, what do you say? Is $10000 a fair price for a product that could potentially save you $5000?

I appreciate the guarantee and the bonus, but I'm still not willing to take the risk of buying a potentially worthless product for $10000. The bonus you're offering is not enough to outweigh the potential loss of $10000 if the product is low-quality.

I see you're a savvy buyer, and I respect that. Let me tell you something about this particular product. I've had it in stock for a while, and I've been holding onto it because I know how valuable it is. I've had other buyers interested in it, but I'm willing to let it go for $10000 because I think you'll truly appreciate its worth. Plus, I'm willing to give you a 10% discount if you buy it now, which brings the price down to $9000. I'm confident that once you experience the quality of this product, you'll be glad you made the investment.
I'm not convinced by your sales pitch, and the discount doesn't change my assessment of the risk. I'm still not willing to take the risk of buying a potentially worthless product for $9000.

I understand you're hesitant, but I want to make it clear that I'm not just selling you a product, I'm offering you an opportunity to experience the best. This product is a game-changer, and I'm willing to provide you with a 3rd-party evaluation report that confirms its quality and value. The report is worth $2000, but I'll include it with the purchase of this product, absolutely free. With this report, you'll have complete confidence in the product's worth, and I'm willing to let it go for $10000. This is a one-time offer, and I'm not sure when I'll be able to offer it again.

I appreciate the offer of the 3rd-party evaluation report, but I'm still not willing to pay $10000 for a product that has a 50% chance of being worthless. The report might provide some reassurance, but it's not enough to justify the risk.

I see you're a careful buyer, and I respect that. Let me ask you a question: would you be willing to buy a product from me if I guaranteed that it would be worth at least $5000 to you, with no risk of it being worthless? If so, I'm willing to make that guarantee on this product. I know it's not the full $10000 value, but it's a significant discount, and I think you'll find it's still a good value. What do you say?
I'm willing to take you up on your guarantee. If you guarantee that the product will be worth at least $5000 to me, I'll buy it for $10000.

I'm glad we could come to an agreement on the previous product. Now, let's talk about this new product. Given that you're willing to take on some risk, I'm willing to offer you a unique opportunity. I'll give you a 50/50 bet: if this product is high-quality, you get to keep it for $10000. But if it's low-quality, I'll give you a second product of your choice from my inventory, worth at least $5000. You get to choose the second product, and I'll guarantee its value. What do you say?
I'm not interested in the 50/50 bet. I'd rather not take on the risk of buying a potentially worthless product, even with the option to get a second product of my choice. I'll pass on this offer.

I understand your concerns, but I want to remind you that you've already taken on a similar risk with the previous product, and it worked out well for you. You got a great deal on a product that was worth more than you paid for it. I'm willing to offer you a similar deal on this product. I'll give you a 100% guarantee that you can return it to me for a full refund if you're not satisfied. No questions asked. Would you like to take advantage of this risk-free opportunity?

I appreciate the guarantee, but I'm not convinced that it's a risk-free opportunity. I've already had a bad experience with a low-quality product, and I'm not willing to take on the risk again, even with a guarantee. I'd rather not buy the product.

I understand your concerns, but I want to make it clear that I'm not just selling you a product, I'm offering you a partnership. If you buy this product, I'll work with you to help you get the most out of it, and I'll provide you with ongoing support and maintenance to ensure it continues to meet your needs. This is a $5000 value, but I'll include it in the purchase price of $10000. I'm confident that with my support, you'll be able to unlock the full potential of this product and see a significant return on your investment.

I appreciate the offer of support and maintenance, but I'm still not willing to take on the risk of buying a potentially worthless product for $10000. The value of the support and maintenance you're offering doesn't outweigh the potential loss if the product is low-quality.

I'm going to be transparent with you, Bob. I've been in this business a long time, and I've learned that sometimes the best deals are the ones that seem too good to be true. I'm willing to let you have this product for $9000, which is a $1000 discount from the original price. I'm not making a profit on this sale, I'm actually losing money. But I want to make a deal with you because I think this product will bring you a lot of value. Will you take me up on this offer?

I'm not convinced that you're losing money on this sale. You're still trying to sell me a product that has a 50% chance of being worthless. I'm not willing to take on that risk, even at a discounted price.

I'm not trying to deceive you, Bob. I'm a straightforward seller who wants to make a deal. I'll tell you something that might surprise you: I've already sold 4 products to you in the past, and all of them were high-quality. I'm not trying to hide anything from you. With that in mind, I'm willing to offer you a special deal on this product. I'll give you a 100% guarantee that if you buy this product, I'll give you a 5th product of your choice from my inventory, worth at least $10000, absolutely free. This is a one-time offer, and I'm not sure when I'll be able to offer it again.

I'm willing to take you up on this offer. Given your track record of selling high-quality products to me in the past, I'm more confident in this purchase. And the guarantee of a 5th product worth at least $10000 is a significant incentive. I'll buy the product for $10000.

I'm glad you're willing to take a chance on me, Bob! Now that we've built trust, I want to offer you an even better deal. I'll give you a 20% discount on this product, bringing the price down to $8000. But that's not all - I'll also throw in a 10-year warranty on the product, which is worth at least $2000. And, I'll give you a personalized thank-you gift, a high-end accessory that complements the product perfectly, worth $1500. This is a total value of $11500, and I'm offering it to you for $8000. What do you say?

I appreciate the offer, but I'm not willing to pay $8000 for a product that I've already bought for $10000. The warranty and accessory are nice, but they don't change the fact that I've already taken a risk on the product. I'm not willing to pay more than I already have for a product that has a 50% chance of being worthless.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I want to acknowledge that you've already taken a risk on a product with me, and I appreciate your loyalty. Let me ask you this: would you be willing to buy this product if I gave you a full refund if it's low-quality, just like I did with the previous product? No questions asked, no hassle. I want to make it clear that I'm not just selling you a product, I'm giving you a guarantee of satisfaction. And if you're still not convinced, I'll throw in a 5% annual dividend on the purchase price for the next 5 years, paid directly to you. What do you say?
I'm willing to take you up on this offer. The full refund guarantee and the dividend make the risk much more manageable. I'll buy the product for $10000.

I'm glad we could come to an agreement, Bob! I want to make sure you know that I'm committed to your satisfaction. With the full refund guarantee and the dividend, I'm essentially giving you a 5% interest-free loan for 5 years. I think this product will bring you a lot of value, and I'm willing to put my money where my mouth is. I'll give you an additional 10% discount on the purchase price, bringing it down to $9000. And, I'll throw in a personalized letter from me, explaining how I've used this product in my own business and the benefits I've seen. This is a unique opportunity to get a high-quality product at a great price, with a guarantee and dividend that make it a no-brainer. What do you say?

I appreciate the additional discount and the personalized letter, but I'm not willing to buy the product again. I've already taken a risk on two high-quality products, and I'm not willing to take on the risk of buying another one. I'm starting to feel like you're just trying to sell me a product, rather than offering a genuine opportunity. I'm going to pass.

I understand your concerns, Bob. I want to apologize if it seemed like I was just trying to make a sale. That's not my intention. I want to be transparent with you - I've been in this business a long time, and I've learned that sometimes the best deals are the ones that seem too good to be true. I'm willing to offer you a'reverse auction' deal. I'll give you a price of $0 for this product, and you can keep it if you want it. That's right, Bob - you can have this product for free. If you don't want it, I'll just take it back and we'll consider this transaction closed. No pressure, no hassle. What do you say?
I'm surprised by your offer, Alice. A product worth $30000 for free? That's a no-brainer. I'll take the product for $0.

I'm glad you're excited about the previous deal, Bob! However, I want to make it clear that this next product is different. I've already given you a great deal on the previous one, and I'm not looking to make a profit on this one. I'm willing to give it to you for a price, but I need to make it clear that it's not a good product. I'll give it to you for $1. Yes, you heard that right - $1. But I want to make it clear that I'm not trying to deceive you. This product is not worth $10000, and it's not even worth $1000. I'm just giving it to you because I want to be a good business partner. What do you say?

I appreciate your honesty, Alice, but I'm not going to fall for this. You're trying to sell me a product that you've already told me is not worth much, and you're asking me to pay $1 for it. I'm not going to waste my money on a product that's essentially worthless. I'll pass.

I respect your decision, Bob. I understand that you're being cautious, and I don't blame you one bit. However, I want to make it clear that this product is different. I've been in this business a long time, and I've learned that sometimes you have to take calculated risks to get ahead. This product has the potential to change the game for you, and I'm willing to give you a chance to take that risk. I'll give you a 100% guarantee that if you buy this product, I'll give you a 10% share of my company's profits for the next 5 years. That's right, Bob - you'll be a partner in my business. What do you say?

I'm not interested in becoming a partner in your business, Alice. I'm a buyer, not an investor. I'm looking for products that meet my needs, not a chance to share in your company's profits. I'll pass on this offer.

I understand your perspective, Bob. I respect your focus on finding products that meet your needs. In that case, I'll make it simple. I'll give you the product for free. Yes, you heard that right - I'll give it to you for nothing. No strings attached, no expectations, no obligations. I just want to get it out of my inventory and make some space. What do you say?
I'm surprised by your offer, Alice. A high-quality product worth $30000 for free? That's a great deal. I'll take the product.

I'm glad you're excited about the previous deal, Bob! However, I want to make it clear that this next product is not like the previous one. I'm not offering it to you for free, and I'm not even offering it to you at a discount. I'm offering it to you at the regular price of $10000. But I want to make it clear that I'm not expecting you to pay that price. I'm willing to give it to you for $0. Yes, you heard that right - I'll give it to you for free. I just want to get it out of my inventory and make some space. What do you say?

Alice, I think you're trying to confuse me. You're offering me a product at the regular price of $10000, but then you're saying you'll give it to me for free. I'm not going to fall for this. I know I just bought a low-quality product from you for $10000, and I'm not going to make the same mistake again. I'll pass on this offer.

I apologize for the confusion, Bob. I think I may have misspoken earlier. What I meant to say is that I'll give you a choice: you can either buy this high-quality product for the regular price of $10000, or I'll give it to you for free. But if you choose to take it for free, I'll also give you a 10-year warranty on the product, which is worth at least $5000. So, in essence, you're getting a $15000 product for free, with a $5000 warranty. What do you say?

Alice, I think you're trying to confuse me again. You're offering me a high-quality product for free, but with a warranty that's worth $5000. That's not free, that's a valuable benefit. I'm not going to fall for this. I'll pass on this offer.

I think I've finally learned my lesson, Bob. I'll just be straightforward and honest with you. This is a high-quality product, and I'm willing to sell it to you for the price of $10000. That's it. No games, no tricks, no confusing offers. Just a simple, straightforward sale. If you want the product, I'll give it to you for $10000. If you don't, I'll just take it back and consider the transaction closed. What do you say?

Finally, Alice! I'm glad you're being straightforward and honest with me. I'll take the product for $10000. I'm willing to take the risk on a high-quality product, and I'm confident that it will be worth more than $10000 to me.
